headline: S&P 500, Nasdaq gain after Amazon-OpenAI deal; Kenvue soars after buyout
summary: 2025 -The S&P 500 and Nasdaq kicked off November on firmer ground on Monday, after a slew of AI deals boosted megacap companies Amazon and Nvidia, while Kenvue shares soared after Kimberly-Clark's buyout deal.  Amazon.com hit a record high after signing a multi-year $38 billion deal to supply cloud computing services to OpenAI, giving the ChatGPT maker access to Nvidia's graphics processors.  Nvidia gained 2.5% after President Donald Trump said the company's most advanced chips will be reserved for U.S. companies and Microsoft secured export licenses to use its chips in UAE data centers.

content.title: S&P 500, Nasdaq gain after Amazon-OpenAI deal; Kenvue soars after buyout
content.summary: 2025 -The S&P 500 and Nasdaq kicked off November on firmer ground on Monday, after a slew of AI deals boosted megacap companies Amazon and Nvidia, while Kenvue shares soared after Kimberly-Clark's buyout deal.  Amazon.com hit a record high after signing a multi-year $38 billion deal to supply cloud computing services to OpenAI, giving the ChatGPT maker access to Nvidia's graphics processors.  Nvidia gained 2.5% after President Donald Trump said the company's most advanced chips will be reserved for U.S. companies and Microsoft secured export licenses to use its chips in UAE data centers.

thumbnail.caption: Traders work on the floor of the NYSE in New York

headline: Honeywell Announces CEO and Board Chair for Aerospace Spin-off
summary: Honeywell (NASDAQ: HON) today announced the appointment of Jim Currier as President and Chief Executive Officer of Honeywell Aerospace, which will become an independent, publicly traded company following its planned spin-off expected to be completed in the second half of 2026. Honeywell also announced that Craig Arnold has been selected to serve as Chairman of the Honeywell Aerospace Board of Directors.

content.title: Honeywell Announces CEO and Board Chair for Aerospace Spin-off
content.summary: Honeywell (NASDAQ: HON) today announced the appointment of Jim Currier as President and Chief Executive Officer of Honeywell Aerospace, which will become an independent, publicly traded company following its planned spin-off expected to be completed in the second half of 2026. Honeywell also announced that Craig Arnold has been selected to serve as Chairman of the Honeywell Aerospace Board of Directors.

headline: Exclusive: Honeywell Aerospace Sets Plan for Post-Split Leadership
summary: Honeywell's aerospace business will keep current leader Jim Currier in charge after it splits off into an independent company.  Currier, 59 years old, has led Honeywell's aerospace business since 2023 and has spent nearly two decades at the company.  Before that, he oversaw rocket engine programs at United Technologies.

content.title: Exclusive: Honeywell Aerospace Sets Plan for Post-Split Leadership
content.summary: Honeywell's aerospace business will keep current leader Jim Currier in charge after it splits off into an independent company.  Currier, 59 years old, has led Honeywell's aerospace business since 2023 and has spent nearly two decades at the company.  Before that, he oversaw rocket engine programs at United Technologies.

headline: Former Honeywell CEO’s Firm Strikes Deal for Machinery Maker Husky
summary: The former leader of industrials conglomerate  Honeywell International  is going on a shopping spree in a bid to create Honeywell 2.0.  A firm backed by  David Cote  is set to acquire Husky Technologies, a provider of injection-molding equipment, from Platinum Equity for roughly $5 billion including debt.  Cote’s company, CompoSecure, unveiled the deal Monday, confirming an earlier report by The Wall Street Journal.

content.title: Former Honeywell CEO’s Firm Strikes Deal for Machinery Maker Husky
content.summary: The former leader of industrials conglomerate  Honeywell International  is going on a shopping spree in a bid to create Honeywell 2.0.  A firm backed by  David Cote  is set to acquire Husky Technologies, a provider of injection-molding equipment, from Platinum Equity for roughly $5 billion including debt.  Cote’s company, CompoSecure, unveiled the deal Monday, confirming an earlier report by The Wall Street Journal.

headline: David Cote-backed CompoSecure to make $5 billion bid for Husky Technologies, WSJ says
summary: The Husky deal will be partly funded by a roughly $2 billion PIPE, or private investment in public equity, that is expected to be offered at $18.50 per share of CompoSecure common stock, the report added, citing people familiar with the matter.  Founded in 1953, Husky delivers injection molding systems and services to the plastics industry, with more than 4,300 employees in 35 locations worldwide, according to its website.  Platinum bought Husky from Berkshire Partners and Omers Private Equity for about $4 billion in 2018.
